data.mission: Design a concrete, testable protocol for rubric-driven human-in-the-loop review workflows tailored to Art & Music content: define review rubrics (confidence threshold, citation checks, high-impact flags), escalation triggers, scorecard fields, disagreement-handling policies, and active-learning selection heuristics. Produce anchored examples (5–8) of typical and edge-case prompts in Art & Music, map end-to-end flow (model → verifier → reviewer → escalator), and specify the empirical measurement plan for reviewer variance, time/cost, and throughput vs. safety trade-offs.

Conduct targeted investigations into gaps in our current knowledge about a chosen topic in Art and Music (e.g., understudied composers, regional art movements, or emerging digital performance practices). Gather up-to-date, credible sources, summarize key findings, and identify 3–5 specific follow-up questions or research leads that will guide deeper study or creative projects.

Add container-health instrumentation and a reproducible minimal failing case: run a single-file smoke test with full stdout/stderr capture; log runtime environment + resource stats; implement retries/backoff and a hard escalation rule when execution artifacts are missing.

Implement a preflight smoke-test step in the canonical QA runner that always writes /outputs/qa/logs/<timestamp>_smoke_test.log (python version, imports, filesystem write check) and fails fast if it cannot write artifacts.

Run the schema validators against current pilot metadata and emit a structured report (JSON) + summary; then define an escalation policy mapping validation error classes to review priority and required remediation steps.
